journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Microfracture for Osteochondral Lesions of the Talus
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review of Reporting of Outcome Data

article-meta.aff: *Hospital for Special Surgery, New York, New York

author-notes.corresp: †John G. Kennedy, MD, Hospital for Special Surgery, 523 E 72nd St, Suite 514, New York, NY 10021 (email: kennedyj@hss.edu).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Microfracture is recognized as a primary treatment strategy for osteochondral lesions of the talus up to 15 mm in size. The ability of fibrocartilage to withstand the mechanical loading of the joint over time is unknown.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to systematically review studies of microfracture for OLT and descriptively analyze the outcome data reported to determine whether it is consistent from one study to another and able to be pooled for systematic review.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A systematic electronic search was performed using the MEDLINE and EMBASE databases. Studies that were published between January 1966 and June 2011 were included in the review. Only studies that reported data specifically on microfracture for treatment of osteochondral lesions of the talus and written in English were included in this review.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Twenty-four studies were included in this systematic review. The categories of general demographics and study design were generally well reported (each over 80% of studies). Patient history and patient-reported outcome data were reported less (55%-66%). Clinical variables (48%) and imaging data (39%) were the least reported in studies.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: There were gross inconsistencies and an underreporting of data between studies such that pooling was deemed impossible. A concerted effort must be made by investigators to ensure that there is adequate reporting of data in studies of microfracture treatment for OLT. A set of guidelines to assist surgeons in reporting data may be useful for future research.

body.p: Osteochondral lesions of the talus (OLT) are recognized as a common injury that occurs in as many as 50% of acute ankle sprains and fractures.48,59 These lesions are often associated with deep ankle pain, a clicking or locking sensation of the joint, as well as impaired function and mobility.46 Although the majority of lesions are linked to a history of traumatic injury,7,21,29,42,48,49 atraumatic causes have also been proposed, including endocrine or metabolic factors,47 degenerative joint disease,54 joint malalignment,27 and genetic predisposition.41 Most symptomatic OLT are unable to spontaneously heal and often require surgical treatment, particularly in the adult and athletic populations.18,31,39 In this regard, numerous surgical treatment strategies have been used with varying success in providing symptomatic relief to the patient and a return to a previous level of athletic play.

Bone marrow stimulation (eg, microfracture, microdrilling), recognized as a primary treatment strategy for symptomatic OLT less than or equal to 15 mm in size, is commonly used in conjunction with excision and curettage of the defect site.‡ No consensus, however, has been determined as to the true critical size defect beyond which microfracture will not work. Regardless of the size of the lesion, the objective of microfracture is to breach the subchondral plate with multiple fractures.52 This process promotes vascularization, and mesenchymal stem cells are released to thereby differentiate into fibrocartilage and fill the defect site.3,9,15,22,39,44 When compared with that of the knee, ankle cartilage has a higher proteoglycan-to-water ratio and a lower prevalence of idiopathic osteoarthritis.58 The talar cartilage acts as an intra-articular shock absorber throughout ankle joint loading.58 Therefore, the hypothesis of microfracture is that this fibrocartilage will act as a buffer or grout to protect the underlying subchondral bone over time.43 However, the ability of fibrocartilage to withstand physiological loading and fluid ingress, as well as provide a clinically acceptable duration of symptomatic relief, remains unknown.

The existing literature on the effectiveness of microfracture in treating OLT varies. Many studies report that microfracture results in symptomatic improvement and good functional outcomes at short- to medium-term follow-up.6,24 Nevertheless, there is a distinct lack of long-term data on microfracture, with some studies beginning to express a concern in terms of deteriorating outcome scores and a degradation of the fibrocartilage over time.5,20 A hallmark of evidence-based medicine is the systematic review of outcome data encompassing the currently available literature on a certain topic. There is a need in such research for the homogeneous reporting of outcome data, which would allow the results to be pooled and compared to propose clinically relevant and accurate treatment guidelines based on the best available evidence. The purpose of this study was to perform a descriptive analysis of studies of microfracture for OLT to determine whether the outcome data reported are consistent from one study to another and therefore able to be pooled for systematic review.

sec.title: Search Strategy
sec.p: This systematic review was conducted in accordance with the guidelines set forth in the Cochrane Handbook. Two authors independently searched and selected eligible studies from the electronic databases of MEDLINE and EMBASE with publication dates of January 1966 through June 2011. This search was performed in June 2011. The following keywords were employed in the electronic search: “(microfracture OR microdrilling OR drilling OR drill OR bone marrow stimulation OR marrow stimulation OR BMS OR arthroscopy OR arthroscopic) AND (talus OR talar OR ankle) AND (cartilage OR osteochondritis dissecans OR chondral OR osteochondral OR transchondral OR osteochondral lesion OR OCL OR OCD).” Only publications written in English were included in this review. In addition, the reference lists of all publications, including systematic reviews found in the search results, were screened for additional articles potentially not identified through our electronic search alone.

The following set of exclusion criteria was used for this study: a combination of diagnoses was evaluated and results not separately described for the OLT microfracture group (ie, confounding variables), follow-up was less than 6 months, and/or the surgical treatment was inadequately described to ascertain whether microfracture was used.

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: A data collection sheet was developed with a list of standardized variables; this sheet was used to evaluate each study included in this review. Thirty variables were recorded as either “reported” or “not reported” for each included study (Table 1). Two independent observers, 1 of whom was the lead author, accomplished data extraction in an unblinded fashion. The lead author validated the extracted data by processing the included studies again after data extraction. Consensus and the senior author resolved any conflicts.

tr.td: Body mass index, symptom duration, history of trauma, activity level
Type of study, number of patients, percentage of patients in follow-up, consecutive patients, follow-up time, lesion measurement method, lesion classification system, surgical approach
Associated injury, associated procedures, lesion size, lesion location, rehabilitation description, diagnostic arthroscopy, second look arthroscopy
Diagnostic radiograph, diagnostic magnetic resonance imaging, diagnostic computed tomography scan, follow-up radiograph, follow-up magnetic resonance imaging, follow-up computed tomography scan
Diagnostic scales, follow-up scales (pain, function, activity), patient satisfaction

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: Descriptive statistics were calculated to evaluate the completeness of data reporting using the list of 30 variables as a guide. For each variable, we calculated the number and percentage of studies that reported the variable. We then grouped the variables into 6 categories of data: (1) general demographic information, (2) patient history, (3) study design, (4) clinical variables, (5) imaging data, and (6) patient-reported outcomes. For each data category, we calculated the average percentage of variables in that category reported by each study. At the study level, we counted the total number of variables reported by each study and the percentage of all variables reported.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Our initial search of the MEDLINE and EMBASE databases identified 1003 articles using the defined criteria. After subsequent removal of duplicates, as well as abstract and full text reviews, 24 publications were identified for inclusion in this systematic review.§

The defined data that were reported or not reported in the studies included in this review are listed in Table 2. In general, the variables reported by the included studies were mixed, and the percentage of studies that reported each variable was sporadic. Table 3 displays the average percentage of variables reported in each of the six categories.

tr.td: Surgical approach used to access lesion
Pain, function, and activity scale, pre-operative
Pain, function, and activity scale, at follow-up

sec.p: General demographic data of sex and mean patient age were each well reported in 96% of studies. By comparison, the data encompassing patient history were reported with a category mean representing just over half of all studies (55%). The individual variables within patient history such as body mass index (BMI; 21%) and activities and athletic participation (ie, activities of daily living; 38%) were poorly reported. A history of previous traumatic experience was well reported (92%).

The variables within the category of study design were all reported in over 50% of studies, with the exception of whether the patient cohort was consecutive (29%). In fact, the data for number of patients, percentage of patients in follow-up, duration of follow-up, the classification system used, and a description of the surgical technique were each reported in over 96% of studies.

The variables composing the categories of clinical data and imaging were the least reported of all (mean, 48% and 39%, respectively) and most inconsistently reported within each study. In the clinical data category, associated injuries and associated procedures were reported in 42% and 25% of all studies, respectively. Lesion size was reported in only 46% of studies. Diagnostic radiographs were used in 88% of all studies. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was reported in 54% of all studies, but of those studies that did use MRI, only 46% used it at both diagnosis and follow-up. Additionally, only 21% of studies that reported the use of MRI indicated the strength of the MRI magnet. Only 2 studies used computed tomography (CT) scan at diagnosis (8%); none used CT scan at follow-up. Collectively, all studies (100%) reported at least 1 diagnostic imaging tool (ie, radiograph, MRI, CT), whereas only 75% of studies reported using at least 1 follow-up imaging modality.

A similar inconsistency was found for patient-reported outcomes. A pain, function, and activity assessment was used preoperatively and at follow-up in 87% of the studies. Three studies (13%) did not use these functional assessments at all. Our review indicated that in total, 23 different scoring systems were used throughout the 24 studies to assess pain, function, and activity levels. Patient satisfaction scales were used in 29% of studies.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The aim of this study was to systematically review published studies on microfracture treatment of OLT to assess whether the historical reporting of outcome data on microfracture can be combined and is therefore adequate to draw conclusions and direct future research. The results from this study demonstrate that in many cases, there were gross inconsistencies and an underreporting of data between studies such that comparing results across studies was not possible. The categories of general demographics and study design were generally well reported (each over 80% of studies), whereas patient history and patient-reported outcome data were reported less (55%-66%). Clinical variables (48%) and imaging data (39%) were the least reported variables.

There are several limitations or potential biases inherent in this review. The search databases used for this study were limited to MEDLINE and EMBASE. Studies published exclusively in other databases, as well as those published in languages other than English, are therefore not represented. The variables analyzed in this review may not be all inclusive of data presented in each publication, but they are a representative summary of the most common data reported. Furthermore, this list of variables may need to be amended in future reviews to reflect alterations in the reporting of data for microfracture by authors over time. Finally, data extraction was not performed in a blinded fashion, but was indeed accomplished by 2 independent observers and later independently validated again by the lead author.

The factors affecting a potential deterioration and return of symptoms in the long term are imperative to understand in high-quality clinical research. It is alarming, therefore, that the variables in the current review that compose patient history (BMI, duration of symptoms, history of previous trauma, and activities of daily living) were reported in only 55% of studies. Specifically, BMI and patient activity levels, which are especially important parameters for patient selection, were reported in only 21% and 38% of the studies, respectively. Previous studies have demonstrated a strong correlation between high BMI and poorer clinical outcome.13

Clinical data parameters were reported in 48% of studies. These parameters include lesion size and associated injuries, which were reported in 46% and 42% of studies, respectively. When reporting associated injuries, it is also important that any concomitant procedures performed be described, as they may affect overall outcomes and therefore must be considered.11,26,34 In addition, numerous studies have demonstrated the importance of lesion size on clinical outcome, which likely has important long-term implications with respect to longevity of fibrocartilage.12,28 Finally, whereas most studies reported the location of the lesion on the talus, most were reported only as a general description of medial or lateral. We recommend that lesion location be carefully reported using the 9-zone anatomic grid previously described by Elias et al.19 Collectively, investigators are encouraged to take care in reporting these important variables, which should be correlated to outcomes of microfracture, allowing researchers to draw conclusions regarding clinically appropriate patient selection.

Imaging studies are imperative in aiding with the diagnosis and subsequent follow-up of cartilage injury and lesions. Plain radiographs were used at diagnosis and follow-up in 88% and 58%, respectively. Although plain radiographs are often used at an initial patient office visit, they do not provide useful information about the articular cartilage and thus are not commonly used at follow-up. The low percentage of plain radiographs at follow-up is therefore expected. In fact, plain radiographs may miss up to 50% of osteochondral lesions in the ankle at the initial diagnosis; therefore, additional imaging techniques are often required.37 Computed tomography scans are useful in preoperative planning for accurate diagnosis of lesion size and location, and the extent of bony injury,25 which may be overestimated by MRI as a result of signal patterns about the talus.46 However, CT scan was used in only 13% of studies at diagnosis. The fact that no single study employed CT scan for follow-up imaging may be expected as, similar to standard radiographs, it cannot evaluate the overlying cartilage repair tissue. Nevertheless, CT may be useful to garner information about the subchondral bone, the healing of which is paramount in the overall spectrum of cartilage healing.

Magnetic resonance imaging is the gold standard for soft tissue imaging, particularly cartilage, and it is commonly used in the diagnosis and follow-up of cartilage defects and repair.16 Fifty-four percent of studies used MRI at diagnosis and 25% for follow-up; 46% used it both pre- and postoperatively. It should be pointed out that those studies that did not use MRI in diagnosis may simply be because the lesions were identified secondarily during standard arthroscopy and then concurrently treated, but this hypothesis was not clearly demonstrable during our review. What is alarming is that only 25% of studies used MRI for patient follow-up after microfracture. One particular study by Becher and Thermann demonstrated good functional results in patients after microfracture, but poor infill of the defect site on MRI with evidence of fibrillation and fissuring in 100% of cases.5 It is results such as these that do report imaging outcomes that provide a cause for concern of deterioration of fibrocartilage over time.5,14,20,36 In this regard, all patients (including those who are asymptomatic) in the senior surgeon’s practice receive a postoperative MRI at standard-of-care time points, which includes 3, 6, and 12 months and yearly after surgery. The studies that do not routinely follow patients postoperatively to monitor cartilage quality may not have the appropriate information necessary to counsel patients on the longevity of their ankle joint or potential need for a future procedure. The use of quantitative MRI techniques, such as T2 mapping, is currently on the rise, as they provide quantitative data on the collagen microstructure of repair cartilage.38 The authors do emphasize that the potential reasons behind the lack of MRI follow-up deserve further investigation and may relate to reasons outside of a surgeon’s desired practice, such as the particular health care system, insurance reimbursement, and/or out-of-pocket cost to the patient.

Scoring systems are an important tool for assessing patient-reported variables such as pain, function, and activity level. Currently, we are not aware of a single validated scoring system for the clinical follow-up of microfracture for osteochondral lesions of the talus. Our review found that there were 23 different scoring systems used to assess pain, function, and activity in the 24 included studies, with the AOFAS Hindfoot score being the most commonly reported. Pre- and postoperative patient-reported outcomes are crucial in determining whether the procedure resulted in improved symptoms and function. A validated scoring system for microfracture in the treatment of osteochondral lesions of the talus would be beneficial, but such a system is not yet available.

This study demonstrates the need for a concerted effort to ensure that there is adequate reporting of data in studies of microfracture treatment for OLT (Table 4). The inconsistencies within studies and general underreporting of data among all studies made it difficult to pool the data, which in turn makes it difficult if not impossible to draw conclusions on microfracture as a treatment strategy for OLT. The current recommendations on microfracture should therefore be critically examined to assess whether the clinical guidelines and recommendations obtained from such are appropriate or warranted.

caption.p: Recommended List of Variables for Studies of Microfracture for the Treatment of Osteochondral Lesions of the Talus

tr.td: Activities of daily living, including athletic participation
Lesion size (length, width, and depth at deepest point)
Pain, function, and activity scale preoperatively
Pain, function, and activity scale at follow-up
When biologics are used as an adjunct
For platelet-rich plasma and concentrated bone marrow aspirate
Volume of venous blood drawn or bone marrow harvested
Cytology of whole blood, platelet-rich plasma, bone marrow aspirate, and concentrated bone marrow aspirate to include

sec.p: As clinicians and researchers, the methods by which data are collected and reported must be described in detail. More importantly, there should be emphasis placed on collecting data such as BMI, lesion size, and activity level, among others, which can have significant effect on patient outcome. In addition, investigators are encouraged to not only collect patient reported outcomes, but also to order imaging studies that provide qualitative and quantitative evaluation of the repair cartilage infill of the defect site. The authors acknowledge that it may prove difficult in some cases to retrospectively collect detailed data from chart review; it is likely much easier in cases of prospective study. Nevertheless, we encourage investigators to implement standard-of-care data collection before and after surgery at defined time points, making homogeneous data collection more manageable. The goal of research on microfracture should be to perform high quality, thorough studies with consistent reporting of data. Reaching this goal will require international collaboration among key investigators to standardize necessary variables for collection and ultimately perform randomized controlled, level I clinical trials comparing other commonly used cartilage repair strategies to microfracture. A set of guidelines from leaders in the field that will assist surgeons in designing studies and standardizing data collection should be considered to guide future research on OLT.

fn.p: An online CME course associated with this article is available for 1 AMA PRA Category 1 Credit™ at http://ajsm-cme.sagepub.com. In accordance with the standards of the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME), it is the policy of The American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine that authors, editors, and planners disclose to the learners all financial relationships during the past 12 months with any commercial interest (A ‘commercial interest’ is any entity producing, marketing, re-selling, or distributing health care goods or services consumed by, or used on, patients). Any and all disclosures are provided in the online journal CME area which is provided to all participants before they actually take the CME activity. In accordance with AOSSM policy, authors, editors, and planners’ participation in this educational activity will be predicated upon timely submission and review of AOSSM disclosure. Noncompliance will result in an author/editor or planner to be stricken from participating in this CME activity.
The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
